EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

City of Orange
Meeks Drive Water Production Plant
P.O. Box 520
Orange, Texas 77631

|====================|
|RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN|
|====================|

The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant is a water production facility that stores chlorine.  Processes occurring at the Meeks Drive Water Production Plant are disinfection of water with chlorine and iron sequestration.  U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) regulation Title 40 Code of Federal Regulations Part 68 (40 CFR 68), Chemical Accident Prevention Provisions, requires The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant to comply with the Risk Management Program (RMP) rule because the quantity of chlorine stored on-site exceeds threshold quantities.  Iron sequestration does not involve any chemicals regulated by the RMP rule.

The RMP rule requires a facility to report the unit inventory for each RMP substance that exceeds threshold quantities, along with an EPA approved chemical release prevention program. In addition, 40 CFR 68 requires all RMP covered facilities to update its Risk Management Program Plan (RMP Plan) within (6) months of an RMP reportable incident or every five (5) years, whichever comes first.  In compliance with 40 CFR 68, the City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant is submitting this five (5) year update to the plan that was initially submitted in 1999 and updated in 2004.  The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant currently holds the following RMP-regulated substances above threshold quantities:

Regulated Chemical	CAS Number	Characteristic	Threshold (lbs)
Chlorine	        7782-50-5       Toxic           2,500


|================================|
|KEY OFFSITE CONSEQUENCE ANALYSIS|
|================================|

40 CFR 68 requires all facilities, subject to the rule, to conduct an offsite consequence analysis to provide information to the public and state and federal environmental agencies about

any potential consequences of an accidental chemical release.  Offsite consequence analyses are essential in identifying potential hazards of accidental release.  The Offsite Consequence Analysis (OCA) comprises 2 elements, a worst-case scenario (WCS) and an alternative release scenario (ARS).


|===================|
|WORST-CASE SCENARIO|
|===================|

An offsite consequence analysis for the worst-case scenario (WCS) was conducted using the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines.  The RMP sets forth specific criteria that must be incorporated in modeling the worst-case scenario.  The EPA defines a WCS as one that results in the greatest distance from the point of release to a specified endpoint.  As defined by the rule, the endpoint for a toxic substance is a specified concentration while for flammables it is a specified overpressure from a vapor cloud explosion (VCE).

The WCS for the City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant operations was calculated using the EPA RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines and the EPA OCA Look-up Tables.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating this scenario.

The WCS for chlorine is a rupture, puncture, or valve failure that leads to total evacuation of the chlorine storage cylinder, which would result in a release of 2,000 lbs of chlorine with a release rate of 200 lb/min.  Based on the release rate of chlorine, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 3.0 miles.  This includes a population of approximately 17,306.


|============================|
|ALTERNATIVE RELEASE SCENARIO|
|============================|

Alternative Release Scenarios (ARS) assess the potential hazards that are more realistic than worst-case scenarios and are designed to assist in the development of emergency response pl

ans.  The RMP Guidelines for Offsite Consequence Analysis were used in evaluating the alternative release scenario for chlorine.  The consequence of this scenario was calculated using the EPA RMP Offsite Consequence Analysis Guidelines and the EPA OCA Look-up Tables.  Although numerous controls are in place to prevent chemical releases and manage such consequences should an incident occur, no credit for active mitigation measures was taken into account in evaluating this scenario.

The ARS for chlorine is a failure of the compression fittings and loss of pressure in the chlorine lines in which the contents of a 15 foot section of 1/4-inch diameter tubing is released.  This would lead to a release of one (1) pound of chlorine.  Based on the release rate, the distance to the toxic endpoint is 0.1 miles.  This includes a population of approximately 27.


|==========================|
|FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY|
|==========================|

The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant, in the past five (5) years, has not incurred any chemical releases that resulted in any known onsite or offsite deaths, injuries, significant damage, evacuations or sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage


|===============================================|
|ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PLAN AND POLICIES|
|===============================================|

The plans for evacuation and accounting for personnel after an evacuation at The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant, are located onsite for all personnel to review.  An extra copy of these plans is maintained at the Jackson Street Wastewater Treatment Plant.

If a release occurs, arrangements are described in the Emergency Response Plan for notification of local emergency response agencies and the public.

The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant is committed to operate and maintain its facility in a safe and environmentally friendly manner.  The City of O

range, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant complies with the rules and regulations set forth by the U.S. EPA Risk Management Plan and OSHA's Process Safety Management Program to ensure the safety of employees and public surroundings.

The City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant designed its accident prevention program to comply with both the EPA RMP rule and with OSHA's Process Safety Management.  The City of Orange incorporates elements addressing the following:

*Equipment Design - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are designed according to recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

*Process Safety Information - Chemical hazard, process technology, and equipment information is documented, maintained up-to-date, and available to operating personnel.

*Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) - PHAs are conducted every three (3) years to identify major process hazard scenarios and to recommend corrective action(s) needed to prevent their occurrence.

*Episodic Risk Management - Periodic reviews are conducted to identify hazards which could have significant community impact and to recommend corrective action(s} needed to prevent their occurrence.  These reviews utilize advanced quantitative risk assessment techniques.

*Operational Safety Standards - Design requirements for active and passive mitigation controls used to prevent major process hazards are documented in operational safety standards.

*Operating Procedures - Operating procedures provide detail on how to safely operate a process and are maintained up-to-date.

*Operator Training Program - The plant has training and testing program, which provides operators with the proper skills and knowledge prior to allowing them to independently operate a process.

*Technical Staff Training and Support - Trained technical staff employees are available 24 hours a day to support operations.

*Maintenance Procedures - The plant has specific procedu

res for maintaining process equipment so that it operates safely.

*Maintenance Training - The plant trains persons who perform routine maintenance tasks on process equipment.

*Mechanical Integrity Program - Vessels (including shipping containers) and other process equipment are periodically tested and/or inspected to ensure safe operation of process equipment, following recognized industry standards and/or governmental requirements.

*Incident Investigation - The plant has a program to ensure that accidents and incidents are properly investigated to determine the cause(s) and to implement corrective action(s) that are needed to prevent the event from reoccurring.

*Employee Participation - The plant has a program to involve employees in prevention program elements.

*Hot Work Permit - The City of Orange does not perform hot work at this site.

*Compliance Audits - Periodic corporate and plant-led audits are conducted to ensure that process operations comply with governmental and corporate requirements.

*Operational Safety Program - The City of Orange has a comprehensive program to ensure that all the elements listed above are implemented at every City of Orange location. This program includes accountabilities for timely and proper implementation of the program elements.

These general prevention elements are parts of an overall management system to prevent accidental chemical releases.  The City of Orange and its employees are committed to the standards that these management systems set, and have specific accountabilities and controls to ensure that they are meeting their own high standards for accident prevention.


|==========================|
|EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM|
|==========================|

Employees at the Meeks Drive Water Production Plant will not be responding respond to an accidental release of chlorine.  Pursuant to 40 CFR 68, Subpart E (Emergency Response), the City of Orange, Meeks Drive Water Production Plant is not re

quired to comply with the emergency response program requirements in 40 CFR §68.95 because the following exemption criteria (listed in 40 CFR §68.90(b)) are satisfied at this site:

* §68.90(b)(1) ¿ The facility is included in the community emergency response plan developed under Title 42 U.S. Code, Section 11003 (U.S.C. 11003).  [The Orange County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) is required to prepare an emergency response plan for this facility since it stores chlorine in excess of the EPCRA §302 threshold planning quantity, which is listed in 40 CFR 355 and is equal to 100 lbs.]; 
* §68.90(b)(2) ¿ Not Applicable; and
* §68.90(b)(3) ¿ Appropriate mechanisms are in place to notify emergency responders when there is a need for a response.  [Employees are instructed to call the City of Orange Fire Department and Police Department in an emergency.]


|=================================|
|PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY|
|=================================|

The City of Orange continually strives to improve its safety related systems.  Its policies and procedures provide the most efficient means to minimize environmental impacts on-site and to the public.  The improvements made by the City of Orange, along with monthly reviews of current safety protocols, reduce the risk of future incidents.
